labs.title: Create your first pod and container
labs.description: Learn how PCAI uses containers by building and running a simple pod.

steps.instruction: Use the web shell to run: kubectl run nginx --image=nginx --port=80
steps.verification: Manual: Check pod status with kubectl get pods

steps.instruction: Examine the pod logs: kubectl logs nginx
steps.verification: Manual: Observe nginx startup logs

completion.summary: Great job! You have successfully completed the 'Create your first pod and container' lab. In this session, you learned about Pods, Containers, Kubectl and how they fit into the PCAI platform.
next_steps: Review the manifest.yaml to understand the resource definitions better.
Try modifying the parameters in the editor and applying changes to see what happens.
Use 'kubectl get all' in the terminal to explore other created resources.

labs.title: Exposing Pods with Services
labs.description: Understand how to make your applications accessible within the cluster using Services.

steps.instruction: Create a deployment: kubectl create deployment hello-pcai --image=gcr.io/google-samples/hello-app:1.0
steps.verification: Check deployment: kubectl get deployments

steps.instruction: Expose the deployment: kubectl expose deployment hello-pcai --type=ClusterIP --port=8080
steps.verification: Check service: kubectl get svc hello-pcai

completion.summary: Great job! You have successfully completed the 'Exposing Pods with Services' lab. In this session, you learned about Deployments, Services, Networking and how they fit into the PCAI platform.
next_steps: Review the manifest.yaml to understand the resource definitions better.
Try modifying the parameters in the editor and applying changes to see what happens.
Use 'kubectl get all' in the terminal to explore other created resources.
Try accessing the service from a different pod.

labs.title: Persistent Storage with PVCs
labs.description: Learn how to request and use persistent storage in PCAI using PersistentVolumeClaims.

steps.instruction:
Create a PVC using the 'pcfs-standard' storage class. Save as pvc.yaml: 
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: task-pv-claim
spec:
  storageClassName: pcfs-standard
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteOnce
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 1Gi
steps.verification: Apply and check: kubectl apply -f pvc.yaml && kubectl get pvc

completion.summary: Great job! You have successfully completed the 'Persistent Storage with PVCs' lab. In this session, you learned about PVC, Storage, Volumes and how they fit into the PCAI platform.
next_steps: Review the manifest.yaml to understand the resource definitions better.
Try modifying the parameters in the editor and applying changes to see what happens.
Use 'kubectl get all' in the terminal to explore other created resources.

labs.title: Scalable Deployments and Services
labs.description: Deploy a multi-replica application and manage its lifecycle.

steps.instruction: Create a deployment with 3 replicas: kubectl create deployment web-server --image=nginx --replicas=3
steps.verification: Verify replicas: kubectl get pods

steps.instruction: Scale the deployment: kubectl scale deployment web-server --replicas=5
steps.verification: Check count: kubectl get deployment web-server

completion.summary: Great job! You have successfully completed the 'Scalable Deployments and Services' lab. In this session, you learned about ReplicaSets, Scaling, Deployments and how they fit into the PCAI platform.
next_steps: Review the manifest.yaml to understand the resource definitions better.
Try modifying the parameters in the editor and applying changes to see what happens.
Use 'kubectl get all' in the terminal to explore other created resources.
Try accessing the service from a different pod.

labs.title: Configuring Apps with ConfigMaps & Secrets
labs.description: Inject configuration and sensitive data into your pods.

steps.instruction: Create a ConfigMap: kubectl create configmap app-config --from-literal=APP_COLOR=blue
steps.verification: Check ConfigMap: kubectl get configmap app-config -o yaml

steps.instruction: Create a Secret: kubectl create secret generic app-secret --from-literal=API_KEY=pcai-123
steps.verification: Check Secret: kubectl get secret app-secret

completion.summary: Great job! You have successfully completed the 'Configuring Apps with ConfigMaps & Secrets' lab. In this session, you learned about ConfigMaps, Secrets, Configuration and how they fit into the PCAI platform.
next_steps: Review the manifest.yaml to understand the resource definitions better.
Try modifying the parameters in the editor and applying changes to see what happens.
Use 'kubectl get all' in the terminal to explore other created resources.

labs.title: Traffic Management with Istio VirtualService
labs.description: Configure advanced routing using Istio's VirtualService within your sandbox.

steps.instruction:
Apply a VirtualService to route traffic to your web-server: 
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3
kind: VirtualService
metadata:
  name: web-route
spec:
  hosts:
  - '*'
  gateways:
  - mesh
  http:
  - route:
    - destination:
        host: web-server
steps.verification: Check VirtualService: kubectl get virtualservice

completion.summary: Great job! You have successfully completed the 'Traffic Management with Istio VirtualService' lab. In this session, you learned about Istio, VirtualService, Routing and how they fit into the PCAI platform.
next_steps: Review the manifest.yaml to understand the resource definitions better.
Try modifying the parameters in the editor and applying changes to see what happens.
Use 'kubectl get all' in the terminal to explore other created resources.
Try accessing the service from a different pod.

labs.title: Securing Apps with NetworkPolicies
labs.description: Isolate your workloads by defining granular network traffic rules.

steps.instruction:
Create a default-deny policy for the sandbox: 
apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: NetworkPolicy
metadata:
  name: default-deny
spec:
  podSelector: {}
  policyTypes:
  - Ingress
steps.verification: Check policy: kubectl get netpol

completion.summary: Great job! You have successfully completed the 'Securing Apps with NetworkPolicies' lab. In this session, you learned about NetworkPolicy, Security, Isolation and how they fit into the PCAI platform.
next_steps: Review the manifest.yaml to understand the resource definitions better.
Try modifying the parameters in the editor and applying changes to see what happens.
Use 'kubectl get all' in the terminal to explore other created resources.

labs.title: Policy Governance with Kyverno
labs.description: Explore how Kyverno enforces policies across the PCAI platform (Read-only).

steps.instruction: List cluster-wide policies: kubectl get clusterpolicies
steps.verification: Review output for policies like 'disallow-privileged-containers'

steps.instruction: Try to create a privileged pod (it should be blocked): kubectl run priv-pod --image=nginx --privileged
steps.verification: Confirm the request is denied by Kyverno

completion.summary: Great job! You have successfully completed the 'Policy Governance with Kyverno' lab. In this session, you learned about Kyverno, Policy, Governance and how they fit into the PCAI platform.
next_steps: Review the manifest.yaml to understand the resource definitions better.
Try modifying the parameters in the editor and applying changes to see what happens.
Use 'kubectl get all' in the terminal to explore other created resources.

steps.instruction: Check sidecar injection status: kubectl get pods --show-labels

labs.title: Deploying Models with MLIS (CPU)
labs.description: Deploy a HuggingFace model using MLIS on CPU-only endpoints.

steps.instruction:
Deploy the 'sentence-transformers/all-MiniLM-L6-v2' model using an InferenceService: 
apiVersion: serving.kserve.io/v1beta1
kind: InferenceService
metadata:
  name: text-embedding
spec:
  predictor:
    containers:
    - name: kserve-container
      image: pcai-registry/mlis/serving-runtime:latest
      env:
      - name: MODEL_NAME
        value: 'all-MiniLM-L6-v2'
      resources:
        limits:
          cpu: '2'
          memory: '4Gi'
steps.verification: Check InferenceService: kubectl get inferenceservice

completion.summary: Great job! You have successfully completed the 'Deploying Models with MLIS (CPU)' lab. In this session, you learned about KServe, Inference, HuggingFace and how they fit into the PCAI platform.
next_steps: Review the manifest.yaml to understand the resource definitions better.
Try modifying the parameters in the editor and applying changes to see what happens.
Use 'kubectl get all' in the terminal to explore other created resources.
